questions.question: Should you share your UPI PIN with anyone?
questions.explanation: Never share your UPI PIN with anyone, including family and bank staff. Banks never ask for your PIN.

questions.question: What should you check before making a UPI payment?
questions.explanation: Always verify both the merchant name and amount before confirming payment.

questions.question: Someone calls saying they are from your bank and asks for OTP. What do you do?
questions.explanation: Banks never ask for OTP over phone. Hang up and call the bank's official number.

questions.question: You get a call saying you won a lottery you never entered. What should you do?
questions.explanation: Lottery scams are very common. You cannot win a lottery you didn't enter. Hang up and block.

questions.question: A caller says they are from police and threatens arrest. What should you do?
questions.explanation: Police never threaten over phone. Visit the police station in person to verify.

fraudStories.title: The Fake Bank Call
fraudStories.scenario: Meera receives a call from someone claiming to be from her bank, asking her to update KYC details urgently.
fraudStories.what_happened: The caller knew her name and last 4 digits of account number. They created urgency saying her account would be blocked.
fraudStories.mistake: She was about to share her OTP when her son intervened.
fraudStories.lesson: Banks never call asking for OTP or personal details. Always hang up and call the bank's official number.

fraudStories.title: The Tampered QR Code
fraudStories.scenario: A customer showed a GPay screenshot as payment proof, but Raghu didn't receive any money.
fraudStories.what_happened: The screenshot was fake, edited to look like a genuine payment confirmation.
fraudStories.mistake: Raghu gave the goods before actually checking his UPI app for received payment.
fraudStories.lesson: Always check your UPI app for received payment. Never rely on customer's screenshot.

fraudStories.title: The Electricity Bill Scam
fraudStories.scenario: Aarav got an SMS saying electricity would be cut unless he paid immediately via a link.
fraudStories.what_happened: The message created panic. The link looked official but was a phishing site.
fraudStories.mistake: He almost clicked the link but checked the official app first - bill was already paid.
fraudStories.lesson: Scammers create urgency. Always check official app/website, never click SMS links.

tips.tip: If someone calls claiming emergency, hang up and call that person back on their known number.
Legitimate companies never ask for passwords, OTPs, or card details via SMS.
Your UPI PIN is like your ATM PIN - NEVER share it with anyone, ever.
Before scanning any QR code, check if it looks tampered or has stickers on top.
If something feels too good to be true (free prizes, huge discounts), it probably is a scam.
